title: 113_s287
content:
The "Helping Homeless Veterans Act of 2013" expands the definition of homeless veteran for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and makes improvements to grant programs for comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans. The "Helping Homeless Veterans Act of 2013" expands benefits for homeless veterans and modifies grant programs to meet the physical privacy, safety, and security needs of homeless veterans. It also increases per diem payments for transitional housing assistance that becomes permanent housing for homeless veterans. Section 2012(a)(2) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to redesignate subparagraphs and adjust rates for homeless veterans' benefits. The maximum rate for services provided to homeless veterans in housing that will become permanent is 150% of the rate authorized for State homes for domiciliary care. SEC. 5 authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans receiving services from grant recipients. SEC. 6 requires the Department of Veterans Affairs to assess comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must assess and measure the capacity of programs receiving grants or per diem payments to support homeless veterans. This assessment includes examining national and local levels to determine if there is enough capacity to meet the needs of homeless veterans in different geographic areas and subpopulations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs assesses program capacity for homeless veterans, sets goals, evaluates program effectiveness, allocates funding, and improves veteran referrals. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding the assessment of programs for homeless veterans and recommendations for improvement within 180 days of completing the assessment. Expansion of VA's dental care for homeless veterans. The eligibility criteria for veterans to receive certain types of care under title 38, United States Code, is amended to include enrollment for care under section 1705(a) and receiving assistance or care in specified settings for a consecutive 60-day period. The eligibility criteria for veterans to receive certain types of care under title 38, United States Code, is amended to include enrollment for care under section 1705(a) and receiving assistance in specified settings for a consecutive 60-day period. This includes settings where the veteran is receiving transitional housing assistance and the Secretary receives verification from the provider of care. The eligibility criteria for veterans to receive certain types of care under title 38, United States Code, is amended to include enrollment for care under section 1705(a) and receiving assistance in specified settings for a consecutive 60-day period. The amendment allows for breaks in care not caused by the veteran to be disregarded. The effective date of the amendment is one year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 8. PARTNERSHIPS WITH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ENTITIES TO PROVIDE LEGAL SERVICES TO HOMELESS VETERANS AND VETERANS AT RISK OF HOMELESSNESS. Section 2022A of Title 38, US Code allows the Secretary to partner with public or private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Partnerships must be distributed across the US, including rural and tribal areas. The Secretary can partner with public or private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, including services related to housing, family law, income support, and criminal defense. The Secretary may consult with public and private entities to develop partnerships for providing legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Entities in partnerships may be required to submit periodic reports on the legal services provided. The Secretary can form partnerships with public and private entities to offer legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The authority for these partnerships will expire on December 31, 2016. Partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. Requests for data to evaluate and improve services provided to veterans at risk of homelessness. Section 2022 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection (f) requiring the Secretary to request data from law enforcement agencies to improve services for veterans at risk of homelessness. SEC. 10. Extension of authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness transitioning from certain institutions. Amends Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code, by extending the program until September 30, 2017 and making other revisions.

SEC. 11. Repeal of requirement for annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, is repealed, and the table of sections in chapter 20 is amended accordingly. Amendments are made to various sections of title 38, United States Code, extending deadlines for treatment, rehabilitation, housing assistance, training entities, and technical assistance grants for homeless and low-income veterans. Amendments to title 38, United States Code extend deadlines for homeless and low-income veterans programs. Section 2064(b) is amended to change the year from 2012 to 2014, and section 2066(d) changes the deadline from December 31, 2013 to December 31, 2014 for the Advisory Committee on Homeless Veterans. SEC. 13 extends the reduced pension for certain veterans receiving nursing facility care by amending the deadline from November 30, 2016, to August 31, 2017. Clerical amendments include changing the section heading and updating the table of sections in title 38, United States Code. Reduced pension extended for veterans receiving nursing facility care, deadline amended to August 31, 2017. Senate passed on November 6, 2013.
